1085225072946745351.text: The attack here is that a malicious callee can change the storage of the caller during a transfer, if the caller doesn’t take precautions. The problem lies in the fact that smart contract developers operated under the assumption that “transfer()” was safe from reentrancy issues.

1085223503404679174.text: After Constantinople however in certain cases changing a storage entry can be as low as 200 gas. One such case is when writing a “dirty” entry, i.e. an entry which had a value previously.

1085223455254069248.text: Currently, it is not possible to make lasting changes in the state with 2300 gas. It possible to make a call to another contract or to issue events. Changing a storage entry costs 5000 gas.

1085223377424605185.text: If no gas is specified, then a fixed stipend of 2300 gas is sent. The recipient can be another contract. Solidity’s “transfer()” feature uses this.

1085223324500836352.text:
A brief explanation follows, will take a few tweets.

In a smart contract transferring value to a recipient can be accomplished via the CALL operation. It is possible to configure this operation to send gas to the recipient.
